title: Court Revives Suit Alleging Foreign Payments to Trump Businesses Violate the Constitution
text:
A federal appeals court in New York revived a lawsuit that alleges President Trump is unconstitutionally profiting from his presidency.

In a 2-1 decision, the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said on Friday plaintiffs representing hotels and restaurants that compete with Mr. Trump’s businesses have legal standing to bring their claims.

The case is among several pending lawsuits alleging violations of constitutional clauses that prohibit Mr. Trump from receiving “emoluments” — things of value — from foreign, federal, state and local governments beyond normal compensation.

The decision, which reversed a 2017 ruling by a federal judge in Manhattan, marks the first time that such a high court has allowed an emoluments case to proceed.

A liberal watchdog group brought the New York case in 2017. Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics In Washington alleged that foreign governments and domestic officials were patronizing Trump Organization properties in New York and Washington to curry favor with the president, giving Mr. Trump an unfair competitive advantage against hotels and restaurants in the same marketplace.

“The Complaint sufficiently alleges that Plaintiffs compete directly with Trump establishments and that the President’s allegedly illegal acts favor Plaintiffs’ competitors,” wrote Second Circuit Judge Pierre Leval in an opinion joined by Circuit Judge Christopher Droney.

The ruling allows the case to go forward, but didn’t address key questions in the cases: what the writers of the Constitution meant by the term “emolument” and whether government payments to Mr. Trump’s businesses are constitutional violations.

But in refusing to dismiss the lawsuit, the Second Circuit parted ways with the Fourth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va., which ruled in July that the state of Maryland and the District of Columbia lacked standing to bring emoluments claims against Mr. Trump. The division raises the possibility of Supreme Court intervention.

The Justice Department—which represents Mr. Trump in the case because he is acting in his official capacity as president—declined to comment.

Deepak Gupta, who represents the plaintiffs, hailed Friday’s ruling.

“The Framers of the Constitution wrote the Emoluments Clause to ensure our elected leaders wouldn’t be corrupted by foreign governments,” Mr. Gupta tweeted on Friday. “Today’s historic victory in the Second Circuit gives us the opportunity to continue the fight to ensure their vision remains alive.”

Circuit Judge John Walker Jr. wrote a dissenting opinion in the ruling. Both he and U.S. District Judge George Daniels, author of the 2017 ruling that was overturned on Friday, thought that the allegations of competitive injury were too speculative and that the emoluments questions raised in the case are better handled by Congress instead of the courts.

“[T]his case is deeply political and thus finds itself in an area where federal courts ought to tread lightly,” wrote Judge Walker.

Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics In Washington dropped out of the New York case as a plaintiff. The organization is counsel to the remaining plaintiffs: Restaurant Opportunities Centers United and Eric Goode, co-owner of the Bowery Hotel, Waverly Inn and other establishments in Manhattan.

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is also deciding whether to revive another emoluments lawsuit brought by 200 House and Senate Democrats.

Mr. Trump turned over day-to-day control of his businesses to his two older sons, but he maintains ownership.

Since Mr. Trump’s inauguration, the Trump International Hotel in Washington has hosted a series of foreign visitors. The Trump Organization has said it donated more than $340,000 in profits it received from foreign governments in 2017 and 2018 to the U.S. Treasury.

The company has declined to specify how it calculates its foreign profits.
